title: Orbital elements
text:
An orbit in three dimensions is described by six elements. They are:

Specific angular momentum
Inclination (\(i\))
Right asceinsion of the ascending node (\(\ohm\))
Argument of perigee (\(\omega\))
True anomoly (\(\theta\))
Eccentricity (\(e\))

Specific angular momentum is given by:
\[
\begin{equation}
\mathbf{h} = \mathbf{r} \times \mathbf{v}
\end{equation}
\tag{1}\]
Angular momentum is calculated by using (Equation¬†1).
Newton‚Äôs sencod law of motion is usually written as:
\[
\mathbf{F} = m\mathbf{a}
\tag{2}\]
The definition of linear momentum is:
\[
\mathbf{p} = m\mathbf{v}
\tag{3}\]
Infact, (Equation¬†2) is actually a consequence of (Equation¬†3).

title: How to find orbital elements?
text:
import numpy as np

mu = 398600.4418
K = np.array([0, 0, 1])

def magnitude(x):
    return np.linalg.norm(x)

def radial_velocity(r, v):
    v_rad = np.dot(r, v)/magnitude(r)
    return v_rad

def ang_mom(r, v):
    h_vec = np.cross(r, v)
    return h_vec

def inclination(h_vec):
    i = np.degrees(np.arccos(h_vec[2]/magnitude(h_vec)))
    return i

#Node line
def node_line(K, h_vec):
    N_vec = np.cross(K, h_vec)
    return N_vec

def right_ascension_of_ascending_node(N_vec):
    if N_vec[1] >= 0:
        RAAN = np.degrees(np.arccos(N_vec[0]/magnitude(N_vec)))
    if N_vec[1] < 0:
        RAAN = 360 - np.degrees(np.arccos(N_vec[0]/magnitude(N_vec)))
    return RAAN

def eccentricity(r, v, mu):
    h_vec = ang_mom(r, v)
    e_vec = (np.cross(v, h_vec) / mu) - (r / magnitude(r))
    return e_vec

def argument_of_perigee(N_vec, e_vec):
    if e_vec[2] >= 0:
        omega = np.degrees(np.arccos(np.dot(N_vec, e_vec)/(magnitude(N_vec)*magnitude(e_vec))))
    if e_vec[2] < 0:
        omega = 360 - np.degrees(np.arccos(np.dot(N_vec, e_vec)/(magnitude(N_vec)*magnitude(e_vec))))
    return omega

def true_anomaly(e_vec, r, v):
    v_rad = radial_velocity(r, v)
    if v_rad >= 0:
        theta = np.degrees(np.arccos(np.dot(e_vec, r)/(magnitude(e_vec)*magnitude(r))))
    if v_rad < 0:
        theta = 360 - np.degrees(np.arccos(np.dot(e_vec, r)/(magnitude(e_vec)*magnitude(r))))
    return theta

def main():
    r = np.array([-6045, -3490, 2500])
    v = np.array([-3.457, 6.618, 2.533])
    v_rad = radial_velocity(r, v)
    h_vec = ang_mom(r=r, v=v)
    h = magnitude(h_vec)
    i = inclination(h_vec=h_vec)
    N_vec = node_line(K, h_vec)
    RAAN = right_ascension_of_ascending_node(N_vec)
    e_vec = eccentricity(r, v, mu)
    e = magnitude(e_vec)
    omega = argument_of_perigee(N_vec, e_vec)
    theta = true_anomaly(e_vec, r, v)
    
    print("h = {0:5.2f} ".format(h))
    print("Inclination = {0:5.2f} deg".format(i))
    print("RAAN = {0:5.2f} deg".format(RAAN))
    print("e = {0:5.2f} ".format(e))
    print("Omega = {0:5.2f} deg".format(omega))
    print("True anomaly = {0:5.2f} deg".format(theta))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

RAAN = 255.28 deg
e =  0.17 
Omega = 20.07 deg
True anomaly = 28.45 deg

title: Automating a Scientific Python Setup: A Gentle Walkthrough
text:
Setting up scientific Python environments used to feel overwhelming to me‚Äîuntil I started collaborating with AI. With its help, I‚Äôve learned how to automate my setup using shell scripts and gained confidence in managing the tools I use for orbital mechanics and data visualization.
In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through a script that sets up a fully functional Python environment to work with Poliastro, a powerful library for orbital mechanics. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or someone looking to streamline your workflow, this guide will give you both a working setup and an understanding of what each step does.

title: Automating a Scientific Python Setup: A Gentle Walkthrough
text:
What We‚Äôll Do
By the end of this post, you‚Äôll know how to:

Write and run a basic shell script
Use conda to manage environments and packages
Install the correct versions of poliastro, astropy, and other tools
Understand why versions matter in scientific computing

title: Automating a Scientific Python Setup: A Gentle Walkthrough
text:
The Full Script (Preview)
Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll build and understand step by step. To get started, copy the code below into a new file and save it as setup_orbitviz.sh. This script will automate the creation of your orbital mechanics Python environment.
#!/bin/bash

echo "üõ∞Ô∏è  Creating conda environment 'orbitviz' with Python 3.10..."
conda create -y -n orbitviz python=3.10

echo "üöÄ Activating environment (if this fails, activate manually)..."
conda activate orbitviz || source activate orbitviz

echo "üî≠ Installing astropy 5.3..."
conda install -y -n orbitviz -c conda-forge astropy=5.3

echo "üìà Installing matplotlib 3.5..."
conda install -y -n orbitviz matplotlib=3.5

echo "üåå Installing poliastro (with all extras)..."
conda run -n orbitviz pip install poliastro[all]

echo "üìì Installing JupyterLab..."
conda install -y -n orbitviz -c conda-forge jupyterlab

echo "üé® Installing Plotly..."
conda install -y -n orbitviz -c plotly plotly

echo "üßÆ Installing numpy, scipy, tqdm..."
conda install -y -n orbitviz numpy scipy tqdm

echo "‚úÖ Setup complete. To activate the environment later, run: conda activate orbitviz"

title: Automating a Scientific Python Setup: A Gentle Walkthrough
text:
Line-by-Line Explanation

#!/bin/bash

This is called a shebang. It tells the operating system: ‚ÄúRun this file using the bash shell.‚Äù
Without this line, the system might not know how to run the script.

echo

The echo command prints messages to the terminal. It‚Äôs a simple way to give feedback while the script runs:
echo "Creating environment..."
You‚Äôll often use this to keep the user informed of progress.

conda create -y -n orbitviz python=3.10

Let‚Äôs break this down:
conda is a package and environment manager, especially useful for scientific work.
create tells it to make a new environment.
-n orbitviz gives the environment a name.
python=3.10 installs Python 3.10 in that environment.
-y means ‚Äúyes to all prompts‚Äù ‚Äî it won‚Äôt ask for confirmation.
Why use environments?
They keep your projects isolated. This way, a change in one project (e.g. upgrading NumPy) won‚Äôt break another.

conda activate orbitviz || source activate orbitviz This tries to activate the environment so all future commands run inside it.

conda activate orbitviz: Standard command for modern conda setups.
|| source activate orbitviz: This part runs only if the first one fails (older conda versions).

conda install -n orbitviz -c conda-forge astropy=5.3 This installs a package called astropy from the conda-forge channel:

-n orbitviz: Install into this environment.
-c conda-forge: Use the conda-forge channel ‚Äî a community-driven source of scientific packages.
astropy=5.3: Install exactly version 5.3.
Why a specific version? Not all versions of Astropy work well with Poliastro. Version pinning helps avoid compatibility issues.
This logic repeats for:
matplotlib=3.5
jupyterlab
plotly
numpy, scipy, and tqdm.

conda run -n orbitviz pip install poliastro[all]

Sometimes, we need pip to install packages from PyPI (Python Package Index).

conda run -n orbitviz: Run a command inside the environment.
pip install poliastro[all]: Install Poliastro and all its optional features.


chmod +x setup_orbitviz.sh

Before you run the script, you make it executable with:
chmod +x setup_orbitviz.sh
chmod changes file permissions.
+x means ‚Äúmake this file executable.‚Äù
Now you can run it as:
./setup_orbitviz.sh

title: Automating a Scientific Python Setup: A Gentle Walkthrough
text:
Why Do Versions Matter?
Scientific libraries like astropy, matplotlib, and poliastro evolve constantly. But newer isn‚Äôt always better‚Äîespecially when libraries depend on each other.
For example:

Poliastro might rely on internal behavior of Astropy 5.3 that‚Äôs changed in 5.4.
Matplotlib might break visualization formatting if you jump versions.

Version pinning ensures a stable and predictable environment‚Äîwhich is critical when you‚Äôre doing simulations or research.

title: Automating a Scientific Python Setup: A Gentle Walkthrough
text:
Want to try?
Here‚Äôs how you can run the whole thing:
# Make the script executable
chmod +x setup_orbitviz.sh

# Run it!
./setup_orbitviz.sh
If something fails (e.g.¬†activation), try this manually:
conda activate orbitviz
And then:
jupyterlab
